Award.AwardTitle: Smart and Connected Health (SCH) PI Workshop, 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal supports the NSF Smart and Connected Health (SCH) Principal Investigators Meeting and Visioning Workshop in Boston, MA on March 2-22, 2017. The meeting brings together principal investigators (PI) of projects awarded by the Smart and Connected Health program from 2011 to 2016. The SCH program was set up in order to bridge gaps in fundamental science necessary to transform health and healthcare, as well as to be focused on prevention and person-centered care. In particular, the Visioning Workshop is designed to address the next generation of challenges in advancing health with foundational research from the computer science, engineering and the social, behavioral and economic disciplines. An objective of the PI Workshop is to provide an opportunity for the principal investigators to explore research progress in a diverse set of funded projects and discuss important current issues, as well as future challenges associated with research in transdisciplinary scientific areas. The discussions will be supported by projects-related posters and further stimulated by cross-talk from the Visioning Workshop. It is anticipated that the meeting will stimulate discussions, connections, and collaborations that will facilitate progress in the area of Smart and Connected Health.

The workshop should have a significant impact on the participants and the future of the Smart and Connected Health program (SCH). The focus of the workshop is on foundational research that supports the growth of smart health within connected communities. The workshop results are likely to include new research directions that will be publicized to the research community through publications and a workshop website. The results dissemination should inform and the developing Smart and Connected Health research community in their transdisciplinary collaboration, educational activities, and spur other innovative research directions. The broader impacts of the workshop are to facilitate progress in the field and stimulate conversations, connections, and collaborations that will lead toward better informed and effective smart and connected health research and resulting technologies for the broadest possible user populations. Additionally, there is a workshop attached to the Principal Investigator meeting that will support the travel for ten students from under-represented STEM disciplines to attend the PI Workshop. This should also help grow the field by providing mentorship and support for a new cadre of investigators looking to do work in the Smart and Connected Health area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Smart and Connected Health (SCH) PI Workshop, 2017 was a three-day workshop held at Boston University to encourage collaboration amongst inter-disciplinary communities to generate solutions and transform the approaches to health and medicine. The program focused on cutting-edge innovations, from smart analytics to bring about personalized health solutions, to devices and algorithms that close the loop and control important physiological variables, and to ways in which humans can better interface with technology to improve health.

The meeting brought together experts, including engineers, scientists, medical doctors, industry leaders, and researchers, who have a stake in Smart and Connected Health. The workshop’s purpose was to identify gaps, needs, resources, and barriers in the community by mapping out a future research agenda that will further scientific development in this area. Additionally, the program focused on using science to bolster ideas that create breakthroughs and innovation.

The first day of the workshop, titled “Visioning,” hosted a forum of more than 50 research leaders. Distinguished colleagues showcased important interdisciplinary work in their fields. Interspersed presentations with breakout sessions in which attendees gathered together in smaller groups to discuss new ideas and presented their findings to the entire group identified the needs and resource requirements to further advance the future of Smart and Connected Health. These presentations covered themes in connected healthcare, big data and analysis, harnessing the power of the Internet of Things to personalize healthcare, and the challenges associated with handling privacy and implementation.

One of the Visioning experts, Professor Edward Damiano (BU) presented the iLetTM bionic pancreas as an example of a smart and connected health system that “closes the loop” by automating the dosing process to treat type 1 diabetes, relieving patients and their caretakers of the burdensome task. Motivated by his infant son David’s diagnosis, Damiano has spent the last 15 years developing the bionic pancreas. The technology optimizes blood sugar levels by using dosing algorithms to automatically calculate and precisely dispense two hormones every five minutes: insulin when blood sugar levels are high; and glucagon when they are low. This was just one of the many examples of advancement in e-health systems discussed during the workshop.

The second and third days included over 140 Principal Investigators who discussed research progress and challenges associated to e-health. Given the transdisciplinary nature of SCH, there are few venues for PIs in this area to convene and discuss new knowledge and collaborate in the areas of resource sharing and defining health impact. The SCH PI workshop was one of its kind in bringing together these diverse disciplines to explore fundamental science challenges and opportunities in the area of health. 

During the “PI Meeting”, 84 participants presented their research and addressed future concerns. These ignite talks disseminated ideas and introduced challenges for e-health. In addition to the talks, poster sessions displaying research were exhibited.

A component of the “PI Meeting” encompassed a funded outreach program for 10 (graduate or post-doctoral) under-represented minorities and women in science and engineering. These groups are notably under-represented in the field of engineering and were provided with career incentives in the e-health field and mentored by a committee for future professional paths. 

The workshop engaged thought by bringing the question of how to use fundamental science to produce innovations that will improve health and the quality of life. Ultimately, participants came together as a community to solve problems with societal value and look to the future. Researchers left the workshop with new directions to explore in the area of smart and connected health, especially as communities become more connected.
